sidebyside.p: Imagine that you are riding on a Ferris wheel of radius 100 feet, and each rotation takes eight minutes. We can use angles in standard position to describe your location as you travel around the wheel. The figure at right shows the locations indicated by \theta = 0\degree,~ 90\degree,~ 180\degree, and 270\degree. But degrees are not the only way to specify location on a circle.

introduction.p: We could use percent of one complete rotation and label the same locations by p = 0,~ p = 25,~ p = 50,~\text{and}~ p = 75. Or we could use the time elapsed, so that for this example we would have t = 0,~ t = 2,~t = 4,~\text{and}~ t = 6 minutes.
Another useful method uses distance traveled, or arclength, along the circle. How far have you traveled around the Ferris wheel at each of the locations shown?

subsection.title: Measuring Angles in Radians
subsection.p:
If you think about measuring arclength, you will see that the degree measure of the spanning angle is not as important as the fraction of one revolution it covers. This observation suggests a new unit of measurement for angles, one that is better suited to calculations involving arclength. We'll make one change in our formula for arclength, from \textbf{Arclength}~ = ~ (\textbf{fraction of one revolution}) \cdot (2\pi r) to \blert{\textbf{Arclength}~ =} ~ \blert{(\textbf{fraction of one revolution}\times 2\pi) \cdot r}
We'll call the quantity in parentheses, (fraction of one revolution \times 2\pi), the radian measure of the angle that spans the arc.

assemblage.title: Radians
assemblage.p: The radian measure of an angle is given by \blert{(\textbf{fraction of one revolution}\times 2\pi)}

subsection.p: For example, one complete revolution, or 360\degree, is equal to 2\pi radians, and one-quarter revolution, or 90\degree, is equal to \dfrac{1}{4}(2\pi) or \dfrac{\pi}{2} radians. The figure below shows the radian measure of the quadrantal angles.

statement.p: What is the radian measure of an angle of 120\degree?

solution.p: An angle of 120\degree is \dfrac{1}{3} of a complete revolution, as we saw in the previous example. Thus, an angle of 120\degree has a radian measure of\dfrac{1}{3}(2\pi), or \dfrac{2\pi}{3}.

statement.p: What fraction of a revolution is \pi radians? How many degrees is that?

subsection.p: Radian measure does not have to be expressed in multiples of \pi. Remember that \pi \approx 3.14, so one complete revolution is about 6.28 radians, and one-quarter revolution is \dfrac{1}{4}(2\pi) = \dfrac{\pi}{2}, or about 1.57 radians. The figure below shows decimal approximations for the quadrantal angles.

statement.p: In which quadrant would you find an angle of 2 radians? An angle of 5 radians?

solution.p: Look at the figure above. The second quadrant includes angles between \dfrac{\pi}{2} and \pi, or 1.57 and 3.14 radians, so 2 radians lies in the second quadrant. An angle of 5 radians is between 4.71 and 6.28, or between \dfrac{3\pi}{2} and 2\pi radians, so it lies in the fourth quadrant.

subsection.title: Converting Between Degrees and Radians
subsection.p: It is not difficult to convert the measure of an angle in degrees to its measure in radians, or vice versa. One complete revolution is equal to 2\pi radians or to 360\degree, so 2\pi ~\text{radians} = 360\degree Dividing both sides of this equation by 2 gives us a conversion factor:

ul.li: To convert from radians to degrees we multiply the radian measure by \dfrac{180\degree}{\pi}.
To convert from degrees to radians we multiply the degree measure by \dfrac{\pi}{180}.

subsection.title: Arclength Formula
subsection.p:
Measuring angles in radians has the following advantage: To calculate an arclength we need only multiply the radius of the circle by the radian measure of the spanning angle, \theta. Look again at our formula for arclength:
\blert{\textbf{Arclength}~ =} ~ \blert{(\textbf{fraction of one revolution}\times 2\pi) \cdot r}

The quantity in parentheses, fraction of one revolution \times 2\pi, is just the measure of the spanning angle in radians. Thus, if \theta is measured in radians, we have the following formula for arclength, s.

assemblage.title: Arclength Formula
assemblage.p: On a circle of radius r, the length s of an arc spanned by an angle \theta in radians is \blert{s = r\theta}

sidebyside.p: In particular, if \theta = 1 we have s = r. We see that an angle of one radian spans an arc whose length is the radius of the circle. This is true for a circle of any size, as illustrated at right: an arclength equal to one radius determines a central angle of one radian, or about 57.3\degree.

subsection.p: In the next example, we use the arclength formula to compute a change in latitude on the Earth's surface. Latitude is measured in degrees north or south of the equator.

statement.p: The radius of the Earth is about 3960 miles. If you travel 500 miles due north, how many degrees of latitude will you traverse?

solution.p: To convert the angle measure to degrees, we multiply by \dfrac{180\degree}{\pi} to get 0.1263\left(\dfrac{180\degree}{\pi}\right) = 7.23\degree Your latitude has changed by about 7.23\degree.

statement.p: The distance around the face of a large clock from 2 to 3 is five feet. What is the radius of the clock?

subsection.title: Unit Circle
subsection.p: On a unit circle, r = 1, so the arclength formula becomes s = \theta. Thus, on a unit circle, the measure of a (positive) angle in radians is equal to the length of the arc it spans.

statement.p: You have walked 4 miles around a circular pond of radius one mile. What is your position relative to your starting point?

solution.p: The pond is a unit circle, so you have traversed an angle in radians equal to the arc length traveled, 4 miles. An angle of 4 radians is in the middle of the third quadrant relative to your starting point, more than halfway but less than three-quarters around the pond.
